Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Science Coordination Office for Summit Station and the Greenland Traverse
Award.AbstractNarration: The Science Coordination Office (SCO) serves the scientific community, NSF/OPP, and the arctic logistics contractor by coordinating input and providing an organized mechanism for OPP to consult with regarding decisions at Summit Station. SCO makes recommendations to CPS about ways to accommodate or mitigate conflicting requests from different science teams, as well as suggesting ways investigators might accomplish science objectives with smaller logistical impacts. SCO advocates on behalf of the community, suggesting science-based priorities for capital investments by OPP at Summit that will maintain and enhance the value of the site for research while striving to keep the station financially sustainable. This proposal includes two new members to SCO in order to represent the broader research community and diversify generations of researchers. This proposal adds functionality to the existing SCO. SCO will discuss research projects on the Greenland Inland Traverse and future research sites on the Greenland Ice Sheet hosting investigations similar to work done at Summit Station. Activities that expand communication in this proposal include significant updates to the current GEOSummit webpage such as incorporation of a virtual tour, Summit bibliography, and Summit GIS. SCO will create a Summit Listserv and host communication events such as a town hall style meeting at the Fall AGU meeting, increased effort at informal direct contact, and semi-annual teleconferences involving the scientific community. The SCO role in long-range and annual planning is to focus on the economic and environmental sustainability of the station in parallel with the preservation of core station scientific activities. These objectives are captured in a developing Long-range Plan for Summit Station.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Science Coordination Office for Summit Camp and the Greenland Inland Traverse (SCO) serves in an advisory capacity to the Arctic Research Support and Logistics Program (RSL).  Our primary role is to present the needs and desires of the science community working on the ice sheet in interior Greenland in discussions and decision making process between RSL and their primary logistics support contractor (CPS).  In order to serve in this role, we also need to be in frequent communication with the science community to make sure we maintain current understanding of their needs and desires, and that we keep them informed about possible or imminent changes in the infrastructure and services that RSL and CPS provide.  The SCO also works with RSL/CPS and science teams to work out equitable and efficient use of resources which can be limited at times, and strives to ensure that the wide range of science and support activities impact the pristine character of Summit as lightly as possible.

 

We share with RSL and CPS a long range goal of redeveloping Summit infrastructure in ways that will reduce long term operation and maintenance costs, and reduce the emissions of pollutants by facilities on the station and the aircraft and traverse vehicles that visit.  Over the past 5 years we have worked closely with RSL and all of their relevant contractors to design a concept for a revitalized Summit station where all core year-round facilities are mounted on jackable platforms, or on sled bases that allow frequent relocation.  These operational changes target greatly reducing the time (and money) spent moving snow away from surface-based structures every summer, and would also reduce emissions from the heavy equipment pushing snow.  Some parts of this long range plan have advanced through detailed architectural and engineering drawings (e.g., the Atmospheric Watch Observatory which will be the focal point for clean air/snow science), while the core station remains at the concept design stage, albeit for exciting reasons.  The Astrophysical research community has recently expressed strong interest in using Summit as a base for telescopes and other instruments to extend the Very Long Baseline Interferometry Network (to image black holes, among other objectives), map the Cosmic Microwave Background, and detect Very High Energy Neutrinos.  Scoping studies to evaluate the viewing and operational characteristics of Summit for these types of instruments/experiments are underway now, results anticipated in the next year or two will determine whether this new group of researchers joins the Summit community or chooses to deploy instruments elsewhere.  If, as we hope, the results are favorable, the scale of Summit core station will have to be expanded to support more people and provide more power.

 

SCO has been an active participant in extended discussions with all interested parties to develop a site plan for what is called Summit/ISI that should accommodate a large influx of Astrophysical research while maintaining long-standing focus on climate relevant research which needs clean air and snow conditions.  This plan will also welcome and support researchers from a range of other disciplines and should keep everyone from inadvertently interfering with each other.

 

The outcomes of our activities focused on long-range planning for Summit and traverse-based science  are reflected in the Summit Vision Statement, the so-called Summit White Paper, A Case for Year-Round Science at Summit, and the Summit Planning Document, all of which are “living documents” (frequently revised and updated) and available on our website http://geosummit.org.

 

SCO also put a lot of time and energy into prioritizing small steps toward the vision that improve the energy efficiency, enhance utility for multiple purposes, and improve safety of existing infrastructure supporting science at Summit.  Examples include extensive review of plans to remodel the Big House, design of the mobile berthing unit, upgrading (skid base, solar thermal heating) the small mobile structure and the flux facility to support summer population peaks, the new mobile garage, and frequent reconfiguration of instrumentation in the mobile science facility and temporary atmospheric watch observatory in response to changing mix of users.

 

Our website is a keystone of our communication to the science community, with several new features added over the past few years (e.g., Google Earth based GIS recording activity in the region over the past 9 years, a virtual tour using Streetview images, a new Working at Summit section targeting new investigators, a comprehensive bibliography of published work near Summit, and a quarterly Newsletter).  We also organized and hosted annual town hall sessions at the past 4 Fall AGU meetings and have conducted GEOSummit conferences the past 3 years; these face to face meetings provide opportunity to keep the community informed about near and long range plans, gather their comments and concerns, and broaden the community by entraining young investigators.
